Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Gromov Hyperbolicity and Besov Spaces in Quasiconformal Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project concerns the development of mathematical tools for analysis on metric measure spaces (spaces with well-defined notions of distance and volume), inspired by basic tools used in ordinary Euclidean space. The work has implications for many fields of mathematics, including dynamical systems, harmonic analysis, and partial differential equations. One useful measurement in geometric analysis is the so-called Besov energy. This project will explore links between the nonlocal Besov-type energy in a compact metric measure space and local energy encoded in the space, as measured through a well-connected super-space that sees the compact space as its boundary. The work aims to use these links to explore how non-local energies are transformed by well-regulated changes in the metric, or distance. Parts of this project will be done in collaboration with graduate students and other early career mathematicians, thus also providing training of the future STEM workforce.

In this project, the principal investigator will develop the potential theoretic tools related to Besov energies by using Gromov hyperbolic fillings of the compact metric measure space so that the compact space is realized as the boundary of the Gromov hyperbolic space. Such a Gromov hyperbolic space is of controlled geometry, and by exploiting this control, the principal investigator will seek to gain control of the nonlocal energies and to obtain information about how these energies are transformed by quasisymmetric maps. The project will also augment the potential theoretic properties of Besov energy by developing the perspective of fractional p-Laplacian (nonlinear versions of the fractional Laplacian).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: In nature, energy of a system or object is of two kinds - local energy and non-local energy. Energy is local if two systems that have the same configuration outside a small region have the difererence in their energy dictated only by their behavior inside the small region, while non-local energies are impacted even by their mutual behavior outside the small region. Local energies are relatively easier to use in obtaining geometric and analytic properties of systems that minimize energy and are therefore in equilibrium, while non-local energy equilibria are more difficult to analyze. The principal outcome of this project is the construction of a method linking non-local energies of systems to local energies of objects that occupy higher dimensional spaces. This was done first for systems that occupy a compact region, by using notions of traces of Sobolev functions in higher dimensional objects, to lower dimensional subregions. Following this, a method of conformally distorting unbounded regions without changing energies of objects in them was used to obtain connections between local and non-local energies even for systems occupying unbounded regions. Subsequently, fractional integro-differential operators were constructed for non-local energies, and as the second principal outcome of this project, analytic and potential theoretic properties of systems in equilibrium with respect to the non-local energies were established. The third principal outcome of this project established a categorization of unbounded nonsmooth spaces of controlled geometry in terms of existence of nonconstant energy minimizers satisfying various criteria such as positivity, boundedness, and globally finite energy.

 

Broader impact: Conduct of research for this project also provided research training opportunity for three postdoctoral scholars, two PhD students, and an undergraduate student at the PI's home institution. In addition, it enabled one of the PhD students to conduct collaborative research visits to Jyvaskyla, Finland, to work with 3 research faculty members and one PhD student there, and in addition, a PhD student from Madrid, Spain, conducted a research stay at the PI's home institution for one semester to gain research experience by collaborating on one of the sub-projects with the PI and a PhD student. The PhD student whose dissertation research was directed by the PI successfully defended the thesis in April 2024. The PI, postdoctoral scholars, and graduate students who worked on components of the project also gave presentations and lectures to disseminate the outcome of the research. During this period the PI also co-organized a Math Research Communities workshop under the aegis of the American Mathematical Society (AMS), and followed this up with annual special session meetings at AMS Eastern Sectional meetings, in order to foster a vibrant and lasting cooperative network between early career mathematicians working in the area of non-smooth analysis.
